div1.p: Reed delights in Emilie Lawrence's love and prays for worthiness.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, June 6, 1875
div1.p:
On this beauti-
ful, bright Sabbath morning, I gladly yield
to the impulse which bids me write a
short letter to you. There is no sermon
to be preached in this Church-land, this
morning; my brother has gone to his ap-
pointment some 10 miles away; sister
has concluded to beckon the God of
Sleep, and I, left all alone, can find no
more delightful employment than com-
muning, for a while, with my sweet Em-
ilie, who, though across the borders of
another state, has been as much present
in my mind, all this bright morning, as if
she had been by my side! Yes! I have
been sitting in an old, comfortable
rocking-chair, (one of those honestly-con-
structed chairs that our fathers and
mothers loved to sit in, when the day's
work was done,) and with my head thrown
back and my hat drawn over my face
so as to exclude the Sun's brightness, I
have been with you in imagination.
In fancy, I saw you mending your way to
the House of Worship, with a sweet smile
on your happy face- Seated in your ac-
customed pew, I saw your head bowed
in the attitude of silent prayer, and
when that prayer had ceased, I beheld
that calm look of devotion which should
ever characterize the Christian woman in
the prescence of her mMaker. I heard your
voice blending sweetly in the song of
praise that rolled up to the Great
White Throne; I looked in your eye,
steadily fixed on the Speaker, as he
told of the trials of the Christian in this
world & of the joys that await him in
the world to come; I watched you, as you
left the Sanctuary, nor did my eye leave
your form till it disappeared across the
threshold of your home; and then as the
thought occurred to me, “that darling
girl loves me, and, in confidence, has
given herself to me, and perchance,
during this very morning, has thought
of me,” I could but exclaim, “Oh Fath-
er in Heaven! what good have I done
to merit this prescious love & this in-
estimable gift”! nor would I repress
the prayer which sprung up sponta-
neously in my heart, “Oh! Father! what
is weak in me, Strengthen; what is im-
pure, purify; prepare me in heart
and mind for the battles of life, and in
all things make me worthy of my
darling Emilie's unbounded love”!
I made no effort to check my flowing tears,
for as they coursed down my cheek,
I felt that my prayer had been accepted
in Heaven, & that Strength would be given
me “in every time of need-” Ah! if I
could tell you, this morning, of my love! I
can't transcribe it on paper, but could
you look into my heart, you would behold
a fountain, pure & inexhaustible, suffi-
cient for Time and Eternity! I know
that you are worthy of all of my devotion,
and I am determined that all of it shall
be bestowed upon you, and to daily
pray that the capacity of loving you,
more & more, may be granted unto me,
one look into my heart would arm
you against all the false alarms
which “older heads” can trump up, &
convince you, beyond the shadow of
a doubt, that nothing but Heaven's
Will(to which I always humbly bow) can
long keep us separated! You would
not exclaim, “Oh! Separation! that checks
the laughter of young hearts;” but rath-
er, “Oh! Time! how rapid is thy flight”.
Do not forget that you must soon be
mine & mine forever! Till that glad
time shall arrive, your sweet self shall
be present with me every moment of
my existence.

Do you know that it would be a source
of much happiness to know that at
some hour of each day you were
thinking of me? A few evenings ago,
while gazing at the Heavens, my eyes
fell upon the planet Jupiter, a
beautiful & brilliant star, which
every night may be seen in the
Southern part of the Heavens, accom-
panied by a smaller star just be-
neath it. While admiring its brilliancy,
I thought to myself, what a sweet
satisfaction it would be to know
that each night, at some particular hour,
my darling Emilie was watching, from
her window, this far off world &
thinking of me! Let us, each night,
my darling, watch this Gem of the
Sky, & while our eyes are turned to-
ward the Heaven, let our thoughts be
turned to each other! Don't forget, in
your next letter, to tell me whether this
meets your approbation-

Last Wednesday, I went to Norfolk,
and, of course, called on your sister
Annie. Had a short & pleasant con-
versation, arranging our future visit
to Harrisonburg- I anticipate a very
happy trip up the country in company
with Mrs. Vaughan- and a pleasant
time after myour arrival- I am expecting
to go to Baltimore soon after I reach
home & spend a few days with Dr
Torney- If I conclude to go, I will write
you, advising you of the fact, soon
after I get home- Shall, probably,
go to Norfolk, tomorrow, & will expect
to find a sweet letter from you, at the
Portsmouth P.O-
